Response: On the whole, our practice is on track to meet our high priority care redesign areas.  We have focused our care redesign efforts on consolidating order sets by disease states among three different EMRs with the goal of reducing variation while also improving quality and decreasing cost.  Additionally, we are redesigning post-discharge care through the use of a care management program, a transitions clinic, TCM/discharge follow up visits, and development of a post-acute network of vested partners.  We have also implemented a community referral system to address socioeconomic barriers.

Coinciding with the implementation of this model, our system went through a merger of two distinct healthcare systems. We have and still are experiencing the usual growing pains that accompany such a substantial change.  While this process might have presented its own distinct challenges, it has also given us a unique platform for messaging the importance of value-based care and the importance it plays in the decisions we are making.

Our Primary POC/Primary Data POC oversees implementation of the model and if they were to depart from the organization, our Secondary Data POC would assume implementation responsibilities with oversight from our Secondary POC.

We routinely review various sources of data at both an aggregate and patient-level for effects of our decisions around care redesign e.g. how shifts in site of post-acute care impacts readmission rates.

Our episode selection strategy has resulted in some Episode Initiator/Episode Type combinations that are resulting in low volumes and thus limiting our ability to identify true opportunities.  We will rethink our strategy for Cohort #2, considering both increasing the number of Episode Initiators for each Episode Type or only participating in those with high volume.
